page.title: 04Farming around Debenham (2)
page.content: Further changes followed.At first,the land was used mainly for grain crops, but by 1980 40% of these had been replaced by oilseed rape.Since 1982, subsidies have been offered for beans, so there has been a further change in the crops grown. Despite the decline of habitat,there has been an increase recently in the number of bee-keepers,all of whom are glad of the replacement of rape by beans.There are now twelve bee-keepers in the area,none of them commercial. One of them has 30 hives,the others fewer than 10. The whole area is criss-crossed with bridleways and footpaths,so Debenham is an ideal village for walkers and riders Paths are not always easy to find since the hedgerows they once followed have long since been bulldozed. Many have been re-routed to follow new boundaries
